issue.name: File upload functionality
issue.description:
The page contains a form which is used to submit a user-supplied file to the following URL:
  • http://localhost:5050/yaml_hammer
Note that Burp has not identified any specific security vulnerabilities with this functionality, and you should manually review it to determine whether any problems exist.
issue.caption: /yaml

issue.name: File upload functionality
issue.description:
The page contains a form which is used to submit a user-supplied file to the following URL:
  • http://localhost:5050/xxe_uploader
Note that Burp has not identified any specific security vulnerabilities with this functionality, and you should manually review it to determine whether any problems exist.
issue.caption: /xxe

issue.name: Input returned in response (reflected)
issue.description: The value of the URL path filename is copied into the application's response.
issue.caption: /xxe_uploader [URL path filename]

issue.name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
issue.description:
The value of the URL path filename is copied into the HTML document as plain text between tags. The payload t6g9k<script>alert(1)</script>qy4es was submitted in the URL path filename. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.
issue.caption: /xxe_uploader [URL path filename]

issue.name: Server-side template injection
issue.description:
The URL path filename appears to be vulnerable to server-side template injection attacks. The template engine appears to be Jinja2.

The payload h5x84{{3 *'4'}}{#commentedout#}{{5*8}}dathy was submitted in the URL path filename. This payload contains a Jinja2 template statement.

The server response contained the string h5x8444440dathy. This indicates that the payload is being interpreted by a server-side template engine.
issue.caption: /xxe_uploader [URL path filename]
